text: Bottle. Chocolate caramel malt and astringent hay aroma. Chestnut brown with moderate tan head. Mildly sweet chocolate caramel malt and mildly bitter astringent hay flavor. Body a bit light. Smooth - nicely drinkable.

Bottle:
Clear, deep rubied/brown with a tall tan head.
Chocolate, roast, dark bread aroma.
Taste is mild chocolate malt, caramel malt.
Just a touch of earthy bitterness.
Very good.

Poured with a nice, full, thick, rich, foamy, textured, light tan head with lots of lace. Odd definite Bavarian Weisse aroma and flavor character to it. Other than that pretty decent. NIce softness to it, both in flavor and body. Good beer.

Bottle. Pours a clear deep amber with a near white head that dissipates quickly to the edges. Aroma has notes of dark grains with a hint of roasted malts, chocolate and toffee. Flavor has lots of bread with a hint of chocolate and toffee underlying.

Bottle. Pours a rich brown with small off-white head. Lacing. Nose is grainy, with a touch of flowery hops and some deeper yeast notes - aroma is somewhat like a whiff of multigrain bread baking. Flavor is simple but good, some caramel notes, a little fruitness, crusty bread, herbs, just a touch of smokiness before a palate cleansing earthy herbal bitterness. A very good old world ale that is rewarding and quaffable.
Bottle. Brown/amber with a beige head. Aroma of caramel and toasted malt. Medium body, caramel, toasted malt, moderate sweetness, but is lacking on the hop bitterness.
12 ounce bottle. Pours a clear, dark amber with a decent beige head. Aroma of malt, grain, and caramel. Taste is malt, grain, caramel, fruit, and a bit of chocolate. Pretty good.

From bottle. Pours a clear brownish-amber hue with an average beige head and some lacing. Aroma is full of caramel, some grains, straw,and dark fruits. Taste is slightly sweet, slight bitter chocolate, some earthiness with a dry finish which lets the hops come out. A little bitter zap on the tongue but enjoyable. Medium body with good carbonation. Not chewy at all compared to a brown ale.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Solid beer. Deep amber almost brown. Light chocolate sweetness on the nose. Caramel, nice malt balance, good stuff.

Bottle poured a clear reddish brown with a small lingering tan head. Aromas of caramel, fruitiness and toasted malt. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of caramel, toasted malt, light earthiness and a hint of fruitiness with a smooth lingering caramel finish.

Schmaltzs Alt is one of those beers that, after enjoying the first few, you hide the others in the back of the beer fridge so you can pull them out when you want something special. The many malts dominate the taste all the way through, sweet and thick without being heavy. Having drank those two bottles hiding in the back tonight, Im looking forward to Schmaltzs return to the store shelf.
Dark tan pour thin fizzy caramel head. Malty and slightly smoky yet light and drinkable.

Tap. Black with tan head. Little aroma. Slightly roasted malt nose. Smooth and Malty. Not a ton of flavor, finishes quickly. Slightly sweet caramel. Easy to drink, not bitter. Its ok , Better Than Expected.

Tap pour at New Bohemia. Appearance leans heavily towards dark cola color. Decent amount of head that stays true. Not much along the lines of aroma. Taste leans heavy on roasted malt. Maybe a little caramel. Refreshing in the middle but end is relatively bitter. An above average Schell but not quite of show and tell.
A well done sessionable alt. Dark amber, medium bodied, sweet, and malty. Tried at the brewery with Vaughn and Amanda.
Doesnt really remind me of true altbier but likea malty amber. It isnt bad but not on style.

12 oz. bottle pours a clear but dark reddish brown with decent beige head and some lacing. Aroma is full of caramel malts some grains and dark fruits.  Taste is slightly sweet with a dry finish which lets the hops come out.  Body is medium with lively carbonation.  Quite enjoyable for what it is.

Bottle at yespr. 
Clear red-brown coloured with a medium sized beige head.
Sweet and malty aroma of caramel and dried fruits.
Sweet and fruity flavour of caramel and dried fruits.
Hoppy finish.

Bottled. A dark amber beer with a yelllowish head. The aroma has notes of malt, straw, and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and caramel, leading to a  dry finish. Thanks yespr for sharing.
12 floz bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a small off white head. Aroma is roasted malty and light overripe fruity. Bitter and toffee malty flavoured. Toffee malty and caramelish finish.
Bottle pour.  Im not even German and I still liked this.  Carbonation is what stuck out as a bit weird to me here.
I love, love, love this beer. I wish it wasnt seasonal.  A cool brown kaleidoscope when poured in the glass. Tasty.Not chewy.
Tap. Pour is brown. Aroma of caramel, chocolate, and nut. Taste is bitter and foul. Some caramel comes through but is dominated by a almost sourness of decomposing grass.

Bottle. Poured a clear dark brown color with red highlights. The head was thin and tan. Fig, brown sugar, and dark chocolate aromas. Light to medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Delicately sweet up front with mild roasty bitterness at the end. Brown sugar and thin coffee flavors.
Altbier? This is as black as a schwarzbier. Flavor is more remisniscent of a schwarz than an altbier. This would be a decent schwarzbier if classified as such, Altbier? No....

Thanks to swalden28 for sharing this bottle. 

The beer pours a dark, clear brown color with a tan head. The aroma, as expected, is very malty. I get a lot of bread and toffee, with not too much else going on. The flavor is also very malty. There is a lot of toffee and caramel, with a little bit of chocolate thrown in. There is also a touch of grass from the hops. Overall, the beer is very dry. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
12oz bottle pours an amber/brown with a medium khaki head. Aroma of chocolate and caramel malts, with dark fruits. Taste similar to aroma with some butterscotch and light bitterness. Drinkable.
Pours a dark reddish brown color with some head. Smells of raisins, and chocolate. Tastes of raisins, chocolate and a hint of caramel. Heavy flavoring with a quick finish. Not too bad.

12oz Bottle.  Pours a light colored brown with some amber highlights.  Aroma of raisins, coco and some roasted malt.  Really light bodied.  Dried, dark fruits, bittersweet coco, and water lead the flavors.  Pretty fast finish.  Enjoyable, but nothing to write home about.

(12oz bottle dated 4-7-11 thanks to swalden28) clear ruby/copper with a tan ring of bubbles. Nose of caramel, melba toast, raisins, but very subdued overall. Taste of dry grain, cream, melba toast, medium thick body and a dry finish.
bottle, thanks to swalden28, dark color of TAB cola with a thin foam, aroma is soft peppery nuts, flavor is caramel , bitter, decent carb but thin
Bottle. Pours brown with beige head. Aroma of faint chocolate and caramel. Flavor is same but a but watered down. Light body, kinda watery. Over all, its ok.

Bottle.  Pours a bruin body with an off white head.  Malty body with light roasted malt tones, hint so coco and caramel with a light sweetness.  THin body with a soft roasted bitterness to finish pretty good.

12 oz bottle via trade with tytoanderso - Pours a brown color with a one finger thick light tan head.  Very light lacing.  Aroma and flavor is toasted caramel malt and dark esters.  Medium body.  A decent beer.  Thanks Ty.
UPDATED: MAR 28, 2012 Decent maltiness, easy to drink ale.  Not especially great but a decent session ale.

Bottle:  A beautiful dark brown pour with auburn highlights and topped by a finger of creamy beige head.  Aroma is malty...  sort of sweet, but nothing more stands out.  Maybe some light toffee and chocolate.  The flavor is where this brew thrives:  Sweet and malty with citrus, caramel, and chocolate.  Earthy with just a bit of citrus hops.  Just a small amount of roast and nuts.  Rich, but increadibly easy drinking.  Pairs well with Reeses Pieces.
This was a definite winner.  Pours a dark brown with a quickly diminishing off-white head.  Roasted hops and caramel flavor with a nice chocolaty caramel finish.  The best schell brew by far!

From a 3+ year old bottle my dad had tucked in the back of his beer fridge. Had no aroma left. Taste was primarily of roast but had a light enough mouthfeel and low bitterness so it wasnt overwhelming. Also some sweetness which made it go down better than I expected. However, nothing to write home about. Was pretty flat which I assume was due to the age of the bottle.

12 oz bottle from the Four Firkins.  Dark chocolate brown pour with a creamy tan head.  Roasted chocolate aroma, flavor is more of the same.  Creamy mouthfeel with a sweet chocolate finish.  VERY easy drinking beer with some great flavor to it.

Color is a dark mocha brown. Thin light tan head the fizzles down quickly.

Smell is of dry roasted malts and slight hints of chocolate. Taste is very similiar, very malty. Hints of dark chocolate also.

Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. Goes down nice.

This is an easy to drink beer for it being dark. Also, it only has 5.1% so you can enjoy a few of these.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-23-2008 05:09:37

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with a thin off-white head. Mild nose of chocolate malt and maybe some dark fruit. Medium bodied, rich chocolate malt flavor, and a little carbonation poking through. Could drink a bunch of these.
Love this beer.... A fantastic mix of Alt and almost porter like depth. One of my personal favs.

12 oz. bottle from Guerde, THANKS!  Served in proper glassware- poured a near black when held to a light source, non transparent, low carbonation, white ring for a head around the glass, sits very still in the glass.  Aroma of a toasted malt, mixed notes of carmel and hops.  Hits the mouth with a high-medium body, malt is very present and delightful- simply delicious, middle holds up well, a bit of vanilla, earth, and faint sweetness on the finish.  Delighting surprise!

12oz bottle.  Opaque brown-black-red color.  Thin, oily head.  Rich and malty, a tad more roasty than the real thing perhaps.  While Id be reluctant to call it world-class, this is a great session beer.  Lots of caramel and chocolate malt tones on top of a smooth easy medium body.  Some background balancing hops are blanketed in the syrupy malt.  A little sticky, but a great beer for an Alt fan like myself.

Poured from bottle into a Summit pint glass - seems inappropriate to drink Schells from a Summit glass, oh well.

Reddish-brown with persistent thin head; very little lacing.

Noble hops, metallic, dark fruits, smells good but a little faint.

Somewhat similar to smell. Reminds me of a roasty brown ale crossed with a Vienna Lager, but with a higher level of hops. Metallic bitterness, especially in the aftertaste, and the bitterness becomes more apparent after continued sipping.

This is the most interesting part of the beer. Smooth and clean like a lager, but creamier like many ales. Very little familiarity with Altbiers, but this makes sense as it is essentially a lagered ale. Medium bodied with a decent level of carbonation - almost spritzy. Ultimately, I am left with creamy but spritzy - very unique, a little strange, but mostly good.

Easy drinking but flavorful.

Dark, caramel-colored body under a creamy sand-colored head. Light metallic notes and a hint of dark fruit to an otherwise full and sweet caramel malt aroma. Caramel prominent in the flavor with mild chocolate. Pleasantly sweet with a touch of roasted bitterness in the finish. ~~~~~~~~~~~~ Single 12 oz. bottle from Corkscrew, Urbana, IL, May 2007

Pours a dark brown with a very thin white head. Aroma is a sweet caramel with some nutty Munic malt and ligh chocolate come through in the aroma but as a whole it is pretty light. Flavor has a very pronounced caramel flavor with a very light nutty and chocolate ending middle with a slight burnt ending. A bit on the super sweet and slightly burnt side for an Altbeir but not a bad beer at all.

Bottled.  Poured clear cola brown with a short-lived cap of off-white head.  The aroma was very sweet with caramel and chocolate leading.. almost a little cherry there, too.. iced tea and cola emerged as it warmed.. very approachable.  The flavor was sweet again with chocolate, black patent, and molasses leading.. some earthy and vanilla accents.. bitterness was light, and it was a tad spicy on the back-end.  Light-medium bodied with low-ish carbonation on the palate.. scratchy and grainy at times.. OK flow.  This was sweet and very easy to drink, but it wasnt too enjoyable.

A cross between a pale lager and schwarzbier. It has that hay and sulphur taste,  but also some sweet caramel. Finish is not very appealing. Rather smooth really. Has a strange extract homebrew taste too it.

Bottle, enjoyed in a hotel room in Springfield.  Poured a dark brown with a small hint of auburn.  Really nice aroma of caramel, cocoa, molasses with a light bit of fruit.  Flavor was not nearly as good, but still ok.  Caramel, roasted malt, and molasses; a bit bready with some minimal hopping in the finish.  Solid stuff.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2009 Bottle into a pint glass. Very dark for an alt -but is labeled as such. Malty flavor and  less hoppy than most alts Ive had. Its still quite good. I did get a bit of a metalic taste when it warmed up a bit but it wasnt off putting. An enjoyable brew.

Pours a very deep brown color with semi loose but medium lasting khaki head and some nice lace. Plenty of roasty malt on the nose with some hints of molasses and a mild fruitiness. Flavor is roasty far more hearty and roasty than a typical Düsseldorf style alt, some very stout like characteristics and some berry and a mild metallic flavors. 
Kind of creamy but just a shade thin on the palate.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Pretty nice.  Lots of malt on the nose, and plenty of boozyness, which is bizarre since this is only 5%.  Very nice to drink.
Bottle courtesy of Dalzale.  Pours brown with a thin white head.  Smells of roses, dark fruit, some citrus.  Tastes earthy and sweet with some carameland a nice spicy bite on the finish.

Pours a dark borwn color with a foamy, tan head. Delicious flavors of chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, caramel, and a bit of molasses are present in this treat. A medium bodied brew, a little creamy, and very tasty.
Delicious dark alt that highlights the roasted and chocolate malts.  Long finish and plenty of weight on the palate.  LIke the comforting cocoa of beer!

Pours dark mahogany brown with a thick tan head.
Aroma is nice roast malt, light chocolate some dark fruit tones.
Flavour is smooth dark roast malt, hints of chocolate and coffee, light vanilla and molasses.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 Pours a extremely dark brown with some larger bubbles and a thick creamy beige head.  Nice aroma of roast, some sweet molasses, and a little chocolate and vanilla.  Creamy mouthful with a little sizzle.  Mellow flavor of roast, vanilla, slight caramel and creamy chocolates.  Finishes dry.  Sweetens up a bit as it warms.   Drinks quickly, Fantastic!

Pours a very dark brown, nearly black. Thick tan head. Aroma is roasted malt with some sweet fruity notes. Flavor start with a nice creamy dark malt. Little bit of a crispness in the finish that doesnt linger too long. Medium bodied. Very easy to drink and surprisingly refreshing.

Thanks 17thfloor for this bottle. Dark brown with red tint and huge long lasting beige/tan head. Sweet semi-roasted malt, a little dirty, nice. Dirty brown malt, sweet, roast, nice. Medium, well carbonated body. Quite nice, one of the best from this brewery.

Dark brown with medium tan head.  Aroma of sweet malts, caramel, brown sugar and toffee.  Taste of sweet malts, caramel and dark malts with some chocolate coming through on the back end.  Smooth and creamy, another decent offering from August Schell.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Naka.  Pours brown with cherry-red hues, topped with a small, half-finger fizzy, dark khaki head.  Nose is mostly caramel with slight chocolate roast and some estery banana notes.  Taste is surprisingly complex, lot of caramel with some chocolate and coffee notes, which are overtaken by a healthy dose of bitter and mild earthy and floral hop flavor.  The beer ends with some mild banana notes which fades slowly to a mild hop bitterness and surprisingly powerful alcohol flavor in the after.  Great mouth feel with moderate to low carbonation.  Delicious.

Pours a dark brown opaque color with a 1 cm light tan head.  Aroma of some roasted bananas with brown sugar and caramel.  The flavor is very roasty with some notes of coffee and bitter chocolate.  A few fruity notes under there, but very surprising considering the aroma.  A pretty rich and creamy body.  Another good offering from Schell.

12oz bottle.  Pours a dark mahogany with a nice brownish head.  Aroma is rather rich, with strong notes of roasted malt and hops alongside subtler hints of caramel, yeast, and chocolate.  Taste is very creamy and rather full, with an initial buildup of tart hops and heavily roasted malt giving way to a long, sweet finish of chocolate, and caramel.  A wonderful surprise from Schells.

Very dark brown/dark amber with creamy head.  Smells like our home smelled when I was young on the farm and grandma would roast barley to mix in with the coffee to make it go farther.  Taste is like something I have always known but never tasted.  Sweet and dark and earthy all at the same time.  To find a flavor like this is why people rate beers.

flat out THIS IS GOOD BEER!.  It tastes the way a good ale should.  There is nothing pretentious or fancy about it.  When i imagine my great grandfather drinking beer, i imagine he drank something like this. (lucky)  Nice color, nice natural head.  great blend of sweetness and a slightly bitter hoppiness at the end.

Big foamy cream colored head, slow fall on a dark brown beer. Strong yeast nose. It has a simple burnt malt and bitter hop flavor. Not to much of any thing. With the simple flavor and the lighter palate I think you could drink these all day long.....In fact, I think I will.

(bottle) Pours reddish amber with an off-white head.  Aroma is pretty sweet with some dark fruit, molasses, and some barley as well.  Taste is initially sweet with caramel, fruit, and as the beer warmed a roasted character was detected.  The beer is medium bodied with a little light bitter finish at the end.  All in all not a bad beer.

[Bottle, thanks Guerde] Pours dark reddish amber with a nearly nonexistent beige head. Aroma is fairly sweet up front, especially shortly after pouring, alternating between a fruitiness and some maple syrup with a lot of caramel, some barley and almost a little nuttiness towards the end. Taste is fairly grainy with a bit of bitterness and barley and roasted malt in the finish. Medium mouthfeel. Good finish. One of the better Schells beers Ive tried and something that would be very sessionable.
Picked this up at Cellars in Eagan.  It has a nice strong malt backbone.  It is one of the more savory beers that I have had this winter.
Very Smooth. This seems stronger that it is at first. The heavy aroma fades and the smooth fine mix holds up.

Poured from the bottle to an opaque dark brown with medium tan head that lingers well and leaves okay lacing. Nose is malty roasted nuts with hints of smoked wood, and the mouthfeel of this medium bodied beer is full and sweet. Flavor accentuates the sweet malty roasted nuts of the nose, and the finish of medium duration and slightly warming.

Alcohol could have been a tad higher for a winter warmer, but an oll round decent beer.
Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma - nutty sweet malt. Flavor dominated by roast malt with some notes of chocolate and caramel. Very smooth with just a touch of hop bitterness on the finish.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2008 Pours dark red brown with a small head that goes away.  The aroma is malty and nice and very faint hops.  The flavor is malty, fruity, caramel - nice.  The palate is medium bodied.  Overall, glad I finally had a chance to try it.

This beer has a very pleasant dark brown to black body with a medium sized tan head. The aroma is a nice blend of malt and fruity hops.  The flavor is a little more malt than hops but, the hops are present with a fruity twang.   A smooth and easy drinking medium bodied ale, with hints of coffee, caramel and chocolate.  This is an outstanding and terrific tasting beer. Far and above the best product Schells turns out.  Now they just need to make it a year around brew.

12oz bottle-An alt beer that is black in body with a nice big tan head which has an aroma of dark malt, chocolate, and some floral. Taste of same with more hops coming through. Not a fan of this style but this beer is good.
Malty, caramel aroma and some fruit notes. Pours a dark ruby brown with a thin head. Flavour has some caramel and nutty flavours. Mid range body with a sweet and dry finish.

I missed sampling this one when it was readily available in Minnesota earlier this year. Thanks to someone who brought this to the RBSG 07 Grand Tasting. From a 12-oz bottle, pours a clear dark amber brew with a thin off-white head that dissolves quickly. Aroma of caramel, floral hops, and roasted nuts. Taste is medium bodied, lightly carbonated, witha good balance of caramel and coffee flavors. Finish is dry with a slight nutty aftertaste.
Sampled at the RBSG 07 Grand Tasting.  Not as bad as I expected.  Malty nose on this cola brown pour.  Watery with malt taste.

nice dark caramel color. smells like a beer should!...aromas of dry roasted malts with some fruity floral hints. when it warms i can catch a whiff of cinnamon french toast without the sweetness. medium bodied and quite creamy. flavor reminds me of beef and black barley soup with a nice hoppy finish. this is one of the driest beers i can remember drinking. nice underrated brew. gotta trade for some more...

A great looking beer to pour.  Thick rich and dark body with a similar head.  The head just does not go away forcing you to drink through it.  This gives a creamy feeling to the beer which is substantial anyway.  Like the aroma, flavor is mostly  malt but with a nice amount of hops.  There is just a hint of bitterness felt on the very tip of the tongue.  Mostly, though, this is a sweet beer.  There are some subtle flavors.  Coffee and chocolate make appearances.  Do I taste banana in there?  Ripe fruit at the end.  A wonderful beer!
Black-cherry with a thin brown head.  Sweet pine, floaral aroma.  Sweet malt, black berry and roasted flavour.  Very smooth start to finish.

Yet another Schell beer that I hate - they are consistent though - a few more from a sampler sixer and I think Im done with the brewery.  Pours mahogany with a crimson hue and caramel colored head.  The aroma is muddled and malty - dark toasted malt, hint of butter, caramel and something that reminds me of a gym locker.  Medium / thin body with tingly assertive carbonation on the finish.  The taste is watery with dark chocolate malt.  The finish has an unpleasant spice and astringency.  Not good.

Pours dark brown, small almond head. Roasted malts mainly with a touch of chocolate and caramel malts and a smokiness in the background finished with what seems to be northern brewer hops with its green leafy taste. Smooth medium mouthfeel and a roasty kick, almost like a black & tan. I think this would be a good change over beer for people new to craft beer.

Having a  bottle of this at Bodega Brew Pub downtown La Crosse, Wisconsin USA. Poured with a nice, full, thick, rich, foamy, textured, light tan head with lots of lace. Odd definite Bavarian Weisse aroma and flavor character to it. Other than that pretty dece. NIce softness to it, both in flavor and body. Good beer. Session beer.

I am sad I found this beer at the end of its run for the winter! I love this style more and more. Pour was a dark brown/almost black with a thin tan head. Aroma of malt and fruit. Taste was like iced tea(?).  I dont know how else to describe it. Thick and complex, yet light and refreshing. A few more Altbiers like this and I may have to change my "favorite style"
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: AUG 11, 2010 Flinty, maltic but well balanced with hops.  Creamy on the tongue.  Hint of cherry on the nose.  Good for sitting around with friends.  Gets better as it reaches warm temperatures

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2008 Ever since I heard the intriguing name schmaltz alt, Ive been wanting to try this.  Ive been very happy, for the most part, with most Schell products.  My interest grew more as I became more familiar with alts, one of my favored styles. Ive also tasted Southampton and Erie alt. This 12 oz bottle has a cool label, though different than the other Schell styles. I am curious if that is Auggie on the front. Once poured into the steeler stein, the color is dark ferruginous brown and a froth of a thin tan head. Ubiquitous beer aroma laced with uncooked bread and roasted background hints. Not overly strong smell. Has a gustatory delight of roasted medium light bitterness. Feels like its trying to be a stout but never gets there with the choler overtones. Interesting and fun to drink.  Frabjous medium low fizz and carbonation, not watered down. Overall a fine example of a good respectable beer.  Finish has a short low to medium malt bitterness.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Its a good beer, for what it is:  An American knock of a German style.  The color is a nice deep red (almost black) color, with a nice ,malty aroma.  It is just missing something to make it more like an alt.

Right out of the fridge, nothing spectacular, but the flavors got much better as it sat in the glass.  I would suggest letting this one sit in the glass for a few minutes if it is coming out of a fridge.  Great head retention, some still visable when I finished.  Lacing all the way down the glass.  Very good aroma throughout.  Another good beer from a great brewery.

Pours a nice reddish black color with a nice dark tan head.  The lacing is very good on this beer and stisk around long after the slowly dissapating head.  Aromas of banana, ripe fruit, bittersweet chocolate and toast.  Flavor is very simple compared to the nose and definately gives some of the chocolate and banana, as well as a slight smokey bite to accent the medium carbonation.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text:
Served at cellar temperature, and poured into my tall, straight-sided Gosser glass, this beer is dark brown with a huge frothy head of tan foam. The head bubbles down in a minute or so. Moderate lacing. Mildly fruity and chocolate malt in the aroma.

Nice sweetish chocolate malt flavor, not overly complex, and truthfully, not really ‘alt-like.’ A nice hop bitterness comes into play in the finish with some additional bitter roasted chocolate malt. Very smooth and creamy mouthfeel, prominent carbonation, and medium body. Very drinkable (he says after polishing off his second and looking for the bottle opener again).

Even though I’m not convinced its an altbier, I really enjoy drinking this beer, and have missed it during its absence. I am very glad it is back. 

As Eric Clapton once sang:

“Hello old friend,
Its really good to see you once again.”

12 oz bottle from Woodmans on Gammon Road, Madison WI (August 2006) imbibed from a Zwiec lager glass at cellar temperature.   Pours out with a huge, fluffy light taupe head topping the dark maple-brown clear body and lacing nicely.....caramel and light herbs in a somewhat mild aroma, hints of cocoa powder and lightly charred malts show up with patience.....very light, effervescent body manages to support a beautifully full caramel-malt flavor, nice light dry woody notes, a hint of sugared pecans....low, natural-feeling carbonation towards the finish, which is a bit drier and somewhat tart/bitter but elegantly done....really juicy and easy to drink; simple but effective.

Finally found a sixer of this at Cellars in woodbury! I had this last year, but wanted to wait to rate till i could taste again. Never had this style brew before but oh so tasty. lacey glass with the head, ruby red color indeed, and very smooth. This might be my fav Schell brew now, to bad its hard to find and not available for long...

12 oz. bottle. Malty aroma with roasted nut notes. Pours a very dark brown with a small to moderate amount of tan head, almost like a porter in appearance. Subtle flavor of roasted malt and lemon with hints of coffee and dark chocolate; quite tasty. Good coffee bitter aftertaste. Full-bodied and creamy but still crisp and drinkable in the palate. Schmaltzs Alt is like a cross between a German dunkel and an English porter. Crazy thought: This might work well in nitro cans.

Pours dark brown with a small off white head. Seems to have a fair amount of carbonation. Aroma is sort of a raw malt and mild chocolate. Flavor is of light malts.  Rather crisp and a touch of sour. Pretty decent beer.
superd alt just tasty deep rich color smooth toffee chocolate etc. one of schells best GET SURLY ROUTES

Pours a five finger, light brown head that fades to a shallow layer leaving traces of lace. Deep mahogeny color. Light carbonation and medium bodied. Strong malty nose.  Starts as sweet molasses becoming balanced at finish, slight burnt molasses aftertaste. New label has ABV at 5.1%.   $1.29 for a 12oz bottle from Johns Grocery Iowa City, IA.

Darker than some alts Ive tried previously.  When held up to the light, this one is gives off a dark brown hue.  Toffee aroma.  Good flavor, chocolately and rich with spices.  Nice.  One of my favorites from Schell.

Looks and smells like an alt.The
deception stops at the taste!Like burnt
coffee and tires.Brew the 2005 Snowstorm year round.

Dark brown color,small off white head.Malty,chocolate aroma with somce hops.malty flavor with a nice roasty side some chocolate and a bit of some hops in the end to round out the experience.Nicely done IMO,one of the few good brews that Schells does besides there DBs and PA.

Dark. Creamy. Kind of an odd beer. Missing that barleywine kick or that altbier taste...but trying for something like one or the other. Ill need to try another or two before deciding for good...right now its ok. Didnt live up to the hype.
(Bottle)  Pours a dark brown body with a small creamy beige head.  Aroma of nuts, toffee, vinous, cocoa, and cookie dough.  Flavor of toasted malt and  licorice with some sourness in the finish.

Pours a very dark practically opaque with a short-lived tan head that subsides into a thin ring.  Aroma of sweet dark caramel and milk chocolate with some German bready yeasty character and noble hops.  Body starts with a full, heavily carbonated caramel malty sweetness turning more bitter and dry toward the mildly earthy bittersweet finish.  Fairly true to style and a nice altbier.

Pours a dark brown amber color with off-white head.  Aroma of caramel malts, grains and dark chocolate accents.  Flavor is quite malty with some coffee and dark chocolate and a mild hop bitterness on the finish.

From a 12 oz. long neck brown bottle with a blurb about the beer on the neck wrapping and info on the side of the front label and a coded bottled/lot/package date and number on the shoulder of bottle, bottled or package on 12/8/05. Made a decent appearance, poured an semi-opaque dark coffee brown with an off-white head that left behind thin rings of sticking. Had largely a clean aroma, chocolate/caramel malty and a light graininess. Moderate carbonation and a smooth, lightly creamy mouth feel, good drinkability. Had a dark malty taste, a mix of chocolate and coffee, a very light sweetness, a slight alcohol presence, a mild soft hop bitterness in the middle and a semi-dry finish.

Pours smooth, dark. Nice thin layer of head that fades quickly. Damn near opaque like guinness. Aroma of candy, bread. Little plum maybe? Taste: YUM, schell, this is your best beer. Youre hurting yourselves with that weak snowstorm this year, "dusseldorf alt"? no no no...  but this.. robust, some coffee, dark chocolate, put well by roder_60 as a "sour/bitter/dry finish". Give this a try!

Pours a nice deep brown with a decent amount of foamy tan head.  Looks yummy.  Aroma is chocolately, creamy milk, with slight sour and tart fruit notes.  Flavor is very very pleasant and well rounded.  Roasted chocolately malt with a sour/bitter/dry finish and almost a buttery undertone.  Overall, I found this to be schells best Ive tried so far.  Great beer!

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2006 This is a new beer for me. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a very dark brown color with a small tan head. The aroma is strong chocolate and what I can only describe as artificial blueberry. The flavor is rich and malty with sour chocolate, ripe fruit and a flowery hop finish. Interesting. I will probably come back to this beer again sometime.

Even though this really isnt an "alt" but more of a porter, I dont understand the low scores.  This beauty is rich and creamy and very malty.  Please if youve reviewed this beer in the past, try it again, I think with an open mind you may really like this beer

Thanks to Grainbeltguzzler for the bottle. Ruby brown color, white effervescent head dissapates quickly.  Caramely malt aroma with a deep hop spiciness behind it.  Slightly fruity ester nose, rich caramel flavors.  Finish is slightly nutty with residual hop spiciness.  Mouthfeel is rather smooth for being an alt.
Man,I was really let down with this as I had high hopes.Must of been better years ago as this batch was watery and tasteless.Sorry.

Very dark for the style.   Roasty and a bit fruity for smell.  Chocolate and slight nuts.  This beer is good in flavor but lacks the bready fell of an alt.  Aftertaste subsides rather quickly.  Smooth malts but this is pushing to a porter.

Rich brown color with a thick, frothy head. Aroma is real light with just some malt. Taste is some chocolate malts but very mild. Slightly sweet with medium carbonation. Head settles fast. I didnt care for this too much.
Transparent brown body, somewhat sticky cream head.  Fruity, chocolatey aromas.  Smooth chocolatey, toasty flavors with a hint of licorice and solid bittering.  Reasonably good.

english pint / clean, small, yet inviting aroma. dark brown body with thick tan head that diminishes in a swift pace, a good ring is left, and moderate lacing is left. malty, fizzy; almost cola like. style description and glassware demands for me to gulp this bad mofo... *burp* believe it or not, this is like a cleaner and less active jaeger bomb!

Poured a dark brown with ruby highlights and a small light tan head.  Aroma of sweet malt, caramel, and dark fruit.  Oddly I also pick up some alcohol.  Flavor starts with mildlt sweet malt and finishes with a light round of hops.  Semi dry finish and light to medium body.

Clean, malty aroma. Little to no hops. Color is a deep reddish brown. Label says 40 SRM compared to 11-19 in the BJCP guide for Duesseldorf Alts. Thick, dense tan head. Head retention is excellent. Medium to big mouthfeel, with roasted malt dominating, a bit of chocolate in there as well. Significant "twang" or bitterness in the back. Label says 28 IBUs, BJCP says 40-60 is appropriate for the style. Smooth and clean finish. Enjoyable, sturdy, well made beer.
Dark ruby brown, tan head.  Flavor is sweet, with a little chocolate, some caramel and dark fruit.  Mild hop finish.  Not bad.
Maybe the best beer Schell makes.  Aroma of malt.  Thick and black, also with a thick head that I dont expect from Schells beers.  Flavor of malt and some smoke.

Almost sugary aroma with hints of roasted malt. Dark almost red colour with a soapy looking thin head that disappeared into a film. It has a good weight to it. A bit of carbonation tickles the tounge. Nice malty taste with some cherry, caramel, and hop notes. Very well balanced malt taste with good mild hop finish.

In the bottle. Mahogany color with a beige head. Complex aroma of horhound candy and medicine. Big supernatural head for a Schell beer. Poofy and fluffy. Thick web of lacing. Can this really be a Schell product? Sweet flavor. Roasted malt with a very mild finish. At first, the hops are non-existent, then you get something of a coffee bitterness at the end. Mild carbonation and a smooth palate.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2005 Interesting filmy head. Aroma maintains a strong air of hoppiness amidst all the malty flavors thrown in. Not truly altbier style but good nonetheless. This is sort of like a stiff porter with much more of a hops balance allowing the flavor nuances of the malts to show through amidst the smoke. I taste lots of chocolate of course (bitter, not sweetened thank goodness). Also there are some caramel and perhaps toffee elements, And to top it all off there is, of all things, an element of citrus to the flavor - cant remember when Ive tasted citrus in a beer this dark! Schnell Schmaltz may be a melange of several elements that is not true to style, but I give it 3 extra Overall points for the uniqueness of the end result!

Bottle. Very dark brown with a reddish hue. Decent creamy tan head with persistent ring of lace. Fruity malt aroma with some roasty toasties to it. Fruity malt flavors with a "chewing on espresso beans" roasted bite coming in. Some dark chocolate and cherry cough syrup thrown in there.  Flavors change often while drinking this one, and become a little more pronounced as it warms up a bit. Interesting and tasty. Not really a traditional Altbier, but good whatever it is.

Deep dark amber brown with a thick latte colored head.  Malty chocolate nose with roasted notes and sweet cherry aromas. Med weight with some sweetness that continues onto the tongue. Great roasted malt flavor with a rich tootsie roll/chocolate quality. Very satisfying flavor that lingers and makes you go back for more. I remember drinking this in college back 7 years ago or so and loving it, for the first time a memory is not as faded as I had thought!

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2006 Pouring a dark mahagony color with a quickly vanishing brown head, this has a mildy smoky aroma mixed with burnt chocolate.  Not a bad roasted flavor, the chocolate coming through on the finish.  Its a little gravelly on the throat.  Not too bad... but thats not a great endorsement.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Calumet City, IL<font size=-1>

Deep dark brown color. Smells fruitty and smokey at the same time. You can taste a lot of dark fruit initially, which is followed by a roasted smokiness. The flavors dont really go well together until the end of the glass.

Thanks to Drnk_Mcdermott for this one.  Pours burnt sienna with a medium off-white head.  Aroma of malt, dark fruit, caramel, cabernet, hops, and slight puke (which makes sense, because puke and dark chocolate both contain butyric acid, and this one had a big dark chocolate taste...I thought it was a schwarzbier before I logged on).  Tastes malty, with black licorice, caramel, nuts, some hops, and raw cocoa flavor.  Medium palate, with a smooth finish.  As it warmed, I got a cherry touch from it.  Nice style.

Pours a very dark brown color with a quickly evaporating head.  Heavy malt aroma that does not disappoint in the taste.  Very thick mouthfeel with loads of barley and chocolate.  It tasted more like a light barley wine than any alts Ive had.  Quite nice!
Brown Coloring.  Small Head.  Barley On The Nose.  Really Enjoyed This Style.  Barley is Evident on the Tongue, but Not Overpowering.  Great Offering From Schell!

12 oz. bottle:  This one pours a very dark brown color.  Some light manages to pass through it.  There was very liottle head on my example.  What was there was tan and died out quickly.  The aroma is mainly that of chocolate.  Some sweetness coming through also.  The taste is a bit roasty, with a subdued sweetness.  A hint of fruits    in the tsate also.  Im sure that ther are hops in there, but they are overpowered by everything else.  Decent.
Pours a dark muddy color.  Nice tan head.  Aroma is is chocolaty.  Flavor is a nice mix between carmel, chocolate and some hoppy citrus.  Nice!
Very dark red color with a light-brown head that sticks around a while. Aroma is a malty toasted blueberry with some chocolate. Taste is a toasted nutty malt with dark fruit. Quite good.

Dark brown w/ an off white head.  Roasty, choclate, malty aroma.  Taste is similar, a little acid, with a dry finish.  Reminds me of a brown ale or porter.  Decent.  Thanks to slikwily for sending me this.

I've enjoyed this brew many times over the years, but never truly stopped to consider it. There's something irresistible about the rhymy name and the label photo of sour Old Schmaltz sitting on a keg, stein in hand.
Color is a dark brown, almost black, with a fine, 1" creamy tan head. Aroma is largely clean and airy, but there are traces of cocoa and nuts. Hops are there, too, but laying low. On the palate, though, they reveal themselves in all their might. Big burst of fruitiness (bananas,and citrus, primarily!), that soon smooths out bigtime. The malt contingent is firm and swiftly becomes large and in charge. That doesn't stop an overriding fruitiness to continue to ride throughout the flavor and the finish. The rest of the drink is a well-rounded, and fruity flavor, with a slightly coppery edge. I'm no expert on alts, but I know what I like, and this is that.

Not necessarily bad, but certainly not very good. The smell was the worst part - it had a horrible cat-food component that I'll never forget. Other than that, the beer was fine. In fact, if it weren't for the smell I'd have thought it quite good. It's just not a beer that I'll miss.
This was one of my favorites. I moved out of the midwest and always thought highly of this beer. It is upsetting that shell has decided to discontinue making it. What a shame.

Not a bad beer! Deep, dark brown.  Roasty and toasty altbier, actually kind of like a schwarzbier. Nice head, sticks around. I would continue to drink this beer, but I apparently can't since it is retired.

Almost mahogony in color with a nice tan head.  Looks good.  The nose is chocolate, roasted malt, caramel.  Not much body and the flavor was unremarkable.  Acidic, light carbonation.  It's retired and will not be missed.

Pours the deepest red with a thin ring of light tan bubbles.  Toasty, woody aroma.  Flavor is surprisingly complex with layers of bread (more precisely, toast) mingling with tangy wood, toffee, and just a hint of raisin.  My second beer of the style, and this one is doing quite a bit more for me than the Old Hat Alt Beer.  Too bad Schmaltz's Alt is apparently no longer produced.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2005 Aroma is walnuts and some sweet bread. Fairly dark almost black color. A large light tan colored head. Bread and roasty flovors. Also notes of nuts and some maple. A very refreshing beer. It has a a lot of flavor for the relatively thin body.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2004 2/4/04 UPDATE: I have to say again how much I enjoy this beer! I bought what might be one of the last sixers in my area recently, since, as rumor has it, Schell is discontinuing this brew! This time, I found the body more thin to medium than my last impression. This is good, as it makes it seem much more alt-like. Great roasted malt flavor, though not overpowering. Did not seem like a porter this time. Who knows what I was thinking last time? Or maybe it was just a slight difference in batches or aging. Regardless, I'm holding on the remaining 5 for as long as I can--and keeping my eyes peeled for any remaining stock on the shelves. This bier tastes good, like a good alt should! PREVIOUS NOTES: Not much like the alt bier I once enjoyed so much as a three-year resident of West Germany (Konigsbacher Alt--I lived in the Traben Trarbach Hunsrucker reigion). That was dryer than this while retaining a lot of malt character. Which is not to say this is bad. It's just that this is more like some other style, like a porter or stout. Pours a dark rich reddish color with a loosely bubbled tannish top that subsides through the drink into clingly lace. Softly carbonated, creamy textured, medium to full body, slighlty caramel in flavor with suggestions of medium chocolate, a certain smokiness, a nice lingering dryness in the finish. Very good. Even delicious, like the label says. But not nearly as good as a good alt.
UPDATED: JUN 8, 2006 Bottled. Brown with garnet highlights, maybe too dark for this style. A surprising smoky quality, but also a taste of adjunct appears to be involved.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2005 this was pretty good stuff, plus I kind of like the picture of the guy on the label

Rerated side by side w/ new glarus native ale.  

Pours a nice deep opawue reddish color, smells of dark roasted malts flavor is a strong dark malty flavor, with a hint of alcohol, and a touch of hops, nice mouth feel this one is the definate winner, despite the fact that it apparently not true to style.

Color of very dark leathery brown nearly black with amber highlights, small but thickly loose tannish top that fades down and leaves minimal spotty lace. Smell is faint mild roasty malts, kinda woodish and wet dirt-like must. Taste is mild, somewhat subdued but present of roasted malts, maybe black malts as well, quite clean with a smokey softness, a bit of cocoa and a over all mineral like taste with a lingering dry finish thats a bit nutty. Feel is a light-medium body, quick thin start, quick thin finish. Nothing to overwhelming, its a very easy roasty calm beer that could be better in the taste but is still a good drinker, goes well with a grilled burger.

Malty aroma, with hints of fruity, spicy hop, dark bread, and a very faint touch of caramel sweetness.  Deep, dark brown in color with a lasting, creamy, ivory head.  Nice balance of roasty, sweet, cocoa and bready malt flavors and the spicy German hop character.  Dry, toasty grain finish.  Very smooth consistency, medium bodied.  Recommended.
I wasnt very fond of this beer. Its flavours were too strong and overpowering. After one i felt full and didnt look forward to another dark german ale. Too much barely flavour for my taste.

As it sets in my glass a deep mahogany, almost an opaque brown, the head is commodious, the texture is creamy and light tan in color, as it erodes the lace formed is a thick and sticky sheet upon the glass. Lots of malt in the nose, sweet caramel, a tad peatish, fresh and appealing, the start sweet, and the top lean in its feel. Finish is stinging in its acidity, the hops pleasing to the palate, dry and lingering aftertaste, a quite quaffable beer at any rate.

Nice dark caramel color and tan head start this one. Aroma is a little sweet and fairly nice. The flavor is nice and fairly easy drinking. A good beer, though lacking something to take it to the next level.

The best brew in Schell's lineup. Roasted malt aroma with hints of cinnamon & nutmeg. You could package this as a winter brew and nobody would think twice. Light brown head, mostly diminishing. Reddish brown in appearance. Nice lacing. Nicely balanced, good flavor. Recommended.

A dark beer with a long lasting head.  Slight caramel aroma.  Very malty taste, it took me awhile to figure out that this beer has more taste and characteristics of a Brown ale than an Alt.  I could find none of the bitterness or bite associated with an alt.  Above average as a brown ale below average as an alt. Disappointing since I was looking forward to an Alt.

Poured very dark ruby-brown with a cola head that was completely gone in short order.  Malty aroma but foreshadowing the metallic notes in the flavor.  The flavor has some other depth, including suggestions of something spicy and something Scottish.  Lots of malts, a bit of bitter chocolate.  Thin, watery palate with a bit of carbonation remaining.  Drinkable and decent, though flawed in some noticeable ways.

Attractive dark red color, not much head, but the head is long lasting and solid. Slighty sweet malty aroma.   Very subtle chocolate taste along with malt flavors and a little bit of hops. This is a surprisingly interesting beer.
Malty for an alt, to me it is better than the more bitter Dusseldorf style alts.  Just my opinion.

The second bottle tastes even better than the first - but two is my limit. Serving temperature really influences this alt; I prefer chilled to refrigerator temperature, then left at room temperature for 10 minutes before cracking. Body is not as heavy as it looks to the innocents. This alt has a strong chocolate nose but is much more complex than the first impression. A friend of mine really loves this mixed with an American lager; about 50:50. I recommend this alt with many German dishes that include sausage. I really like the finish.

Well I opened this one up and poured in to my glass.  Schmelled like new auto paint and then believe it or not like bananas.  Tasted like a strong caramel and a taste I cant put my fingers on.  I liked the overall taste but wouldnt want to taste it on a regular basis.
worst of the schell offerings. overall its a drinkable beer, but poor ratings for trying to pass it off as an alt. too dark and dry for the style. had more of a dunkel lager character.

An interesting beer, but not very complex. Pours out to a amber, almost brown color. Somewhat sweet with a light hop presence on the finish. I honestly can say I liked it but wished it were a little more flavorful. The Schell Brewery is a nice thing for the folks in Minnesota and the Midwest to have around.
Nice malt flavor, and a compliment of hoppy bitterness.  The palate is nice, but seems a little thin after the bitterness.
A classic from schell brewing.  Wonderful aroma and great looking brown color in the glass.  Nice toasted malt with slight chocolate and carmel flavor.
very malty light bitterness nothing that cant be handled good finish  worth trying again and again
Brown color,roasty malty aroma, brown color, taste of chocolate and caremel, a very balanced Alt, very good.

a very malty alt.  medium to thick palate.  dark brown body.  Roasted chocolate abounds, as well as a large amount of sourness (this, I did not like).  Some chalkiness ensues.  Moderate hops.  Nowhere near BlimpCity, but well done anyway.
very malty aroma with a nice roasty quality...flavor is impressively roasted. didnt detect as much bitterness as other raters.
A gooood dark beer.  Nice chocolately malty flavor.  Great aroma.  Very complex and good.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2004 I have been waiting a really long time to try this, then the place in Jackson got it in. I think it's my first altbier.
Dark with really small bubbly head, lasting as a super thin rim. Thin-to-medium bodied. Dark choc malt in the nose, but awash with other malts as well. A bit sour through the middle. Good hop finish. I liked this...it seems complex. This first bottle I didn't even let get all the way cold, and I'm glad. Warming does the flavors justice. But, another one of these later I need to ask: is it supposed to have this lactic sourness?
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text:
UPDATED: AUG 14, 2006 UPDATEII (August 24, 2003): Id heard that Schells was discontinuing this brew so I ran out and got another sixer.  Still the same great combination of tastes as Ive come to know & love.  This is one of my top beers, for good reason--nice palate,  great taste and it also looks nice in my trusty ale tumbler. I really hope they dont pull the plug on this! UPDATE:  The second batch I tried is even better than the first!  Lots of malt flavor with a follow-up of hops near the end.  This is great beer!

INITIAL RATING:  Id seen this stuff in the cooler at our local beer outlet for a long time but never gave it a go...now Im kicking myself for waiting so long.  This stuff is great.  Id never tried an alt style beer before so this is my first taste.  Because of that, its tough for me to compare it with anything else.  It has a nice, malty character without being sweet and comes through with a nice hoppy finish.

I really like it!
Are there actually hops in this sucker? Its hard to tell because all you can taste are the malts. Thats OK -- this is an excellent dark, rich altbier.

This wasnt my favorite Schells offering for a long time.  I had at least one rough bottle and then my trip to the brewery didnt really change my mind either.  It reminded me a lot of my home made stout, before it was appropriately aged.  With so much malt it is easy to get wierd flavors.  I recently gave it another chance, or rather my husband brought home a six pack as part of showing off Minnesota beers to his relatives.  I think Schells has finally gotten it right.  There is no roughness, only smooth choclate malt flavor.  Yum.
vey malty and smooth not rich tasting sweet just malty and smooth to the finnish

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2003 Original Rate 3 June, '02 This is the beer that started my beer tasting quest many years ago, so it holds a special place in my heart/stomach.  Dark blown color with a dark cream thick head.  Chocolate and roast malt flavors along with a mind hop bitterness.  Very satisfying. Rating 8/4/9/3/19.  RERATE 30 Sept, '03 OK so my benevolence for this brew should be over.  I still enjoy this brew, but perhaps my praises are based on this being the epiphany of brews. Chocolate and green hops aroma. Rich and thick in palate. A bit thin in flavor with caramel mocha flavors dominating.

Very little aroma. Nice red-brown color, with small head - lacing. Smooth, watery palate. This was a bit sour (normal?) and had a coppery taste. Had some altbier character in the flavor, but was more appealing when washing down dinner, not sipped by itself.
A nice creamy dark malt.  Aftertaste is somewhat sour, but overall a good beer.

this is different than most beers i drink, but it wasnt bad-just not my style-good, robust malts-chocolate throghout with a spicy finsih, similar to alot of holiday ales such as Breckenridge Christmas and goose island christmas, just not as good or strong.
A work of Alt - rich and mysterious with warm chocolate tones and a hint of spicy yeast in the finish.

I cant believe Id waited this long to try this one.  This is a little more choclatey than I expected, but it tastes good.  Clean yeast effects let the multilayered malt flavors shine through.  Nice balanced hops in the finish.  Theres a lot of bang here, both for your buck and alcohol content.
Lovely beer - rich and warm and satisfying.
Hated it.  Bitter, dark, and bad.  Brush your teeth afterwards to loosen all the barley from your teeth.
Nice beer, balanced well with chocolate flavors and a flavorful hoppy finish.
Has a dark appearance similar to an oatmeal stout.  A chocolate roasty malt flavor with a slightly bitter aftertaste.  Pretty interesting overall.
good balance - makes me want to try others of this style

This is my wifes favorite beer (other than some homebrews).  It is probably better when considered as a moderatly hopped porter than as an Altbeer.   Big chocolate malt flavors and a good body with a well balance bitterness and restrained spicy hop character.
Buttery malt flavour, slightly chocolatey.  Dark for the style.
Very dark for an alt, some what of a chocolaty aroma.  Nothing special.
